BeeFacts: Honey bees are great flyers. They fly at a speed of around 25km per hour and beat their wings 200 times per second.
The average worker bee lives for just five to six weeks. During this time, she’ll produce around a twelfth of a teaspoon of honey
To communicate information about food sources, they perform a 'waggle dance' where they move their body in a figure eight and wiggle around to indicate the direction of the food source
In some regions of the world, up to 90% of the bee populations have disappeared. This is known as 'colony collapse disorder'.
Honey bees are very important pollinators for flowers, fruit and vegetables. They transfer pollen, allowing the plant to produce seeds or fruit
There are about 20,000 species of bees around the world, and only 7 species are recognized as honey bees.
The honey bee brain is incredibly sophisticated, even though it's the size of a grain of sugar.
All bees in a hive are aware of the presence of the queen bee. If she leaves the hive, every other bees knows it within 15 minutes.
Bees have been trained as bomb detectors and can detect hidden landmines.
One third of the food we eat is pollinated by honey bees.
Honey bees pollinate 80% of our agricultural crops.
The U.S population of honey bees has declined 60% since the 1940's.
Diseases and parasites contribute to the decline in bee populations. Threats include Varroa mites and German yellow jackets.
